Seiju Elm

10 April 2016 on blog

What's that?

That's an Elm. A Bonsai Elm.

Actually, not Bonsai. Saikei, which is not as restrictive as Bonsai, yet impressive as well.

And by the way, that's not just an Elm, but a Seiju elm, which is very good for Bonsai/Saikei practices. E.g. their leaves can shrink a lot, for huge impact as a miniature tree.

But anyways, What does it has to do with this?

Well, as part of the roadmap I mentioned that I switched my preference from NodeJS to Elixir. It was natural that I will look for a way to carry over the "functional" paradigm to the front end as well.

Enter Elm. At this point, the plans to use more React and Polymer are on hold, replaced by the introduction of Elm in the roadmap.

On the plus side, this is pretty awesome because now I can do everything via functions, and following atomic design principles in a very elegant way.

Minus points because I don't know much about elm yet, so I'm expecting a lot of delays in my plans because of it.

I am not going to do a lot with Elm though. Just the basics. And keep the code as small as possible (hence the Saikei reference). In other words, don't expect an elm-package developed by me.

As for the eco-system, is my intention to create the front end code with Elm and connect the backend via Phoenix APIs. Eventually (and depending on the need), I would like to try Elm directly within Phoenix, but by then I hope there will be more blogs around Elm and Phoenix that can help me on my quest.

No trip to Australia this month though :(

54chi
